standard_metadata.standard_description: Compare two decimals to hundredths by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two decimals refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual model.

question.content: **Compare the decimals with $>,<,$ or $=$.**   *Hint: Think about how you would fill in each grid below to help you compare the decimals.*  $0.17$  $0.2$

images.alt: A big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 rows of 10 squares each. In all 10 rows, all 10 squares are not shaded.
A big square is divided into 10 equal horizontal rectangles. All 10 rectangles are not shaded.

0.17 equals a big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 rows of 10 squares each. In the bottom row, all 10 squares are shaded. In the second row from the bottom, the left 7 squares are shaded.
0.2 equals a big square divided into 10 equal horizontal rectangles. Two rectangles from the bottom are shaded. The remaining 8 rectangles are not shaded.

hints.content: $\green{0.17}$ covers **less** area than $\blue{0.2}$, so $\green{0.17}$ is **less** than $\blue{0.2}$.

question.content: **Compare the decimals with $>,<,$ or $=$.**   *Hint: Think about how you would fill in each grid below to help you compare the decimals.*  $0.08$  $0.6$

images.alt: A big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 rows of 10 squares each. In all 10 rows, all 10 squares are not shaded.
A big square is divided into 10 equal horizontal rectangles. All 10 rectangles are not shaded.
0.08 equals a big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 rows of 10 squares each. In the bottom row, the left 8 squares are shaded.
0.6 equals a big square divided into 10 equal horizontal rectangles. Six rectangles from the bottom are shaded. The remaining 4 rectangles are not shaded.

hints.content: $\green{0.08}$ covers **less** area than $\blue{0.6}$, so $\green{0.08}$ is **less** than $\blue{0.6}$.

question.content: **Compare the decimals with $>,<,$ or $=$.**   *Hint: Think about how you would fill in each grid below to help you compare the decimals.*  $0.5$  $0.52$

images.alt: A big square is divided into 10 equal vertical rectangles. All 10 rectangles are not shaded.
A big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 rows of 10 squares each. In all 10 rows, all 10 squares are not shaded.
0.5 equals a big square divided into 10 equal vertical rectangles. Five rectangles from the left are shaded. The remaining 5 rectangles are not shaded.

0.52 equals a big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 columns of 10 squares each. In the left 5 columns, all 10 squares are shaded. In the sixth column from the left, the bottom 2 squares are shaded.

hints.content: $\green{0.5}$ covers **less** area than $\blue{0.52}$, so $\green{0.5}$ is **less** than $\blue{0.52}$.

A big square is divided into 10 equal vertical rectangles. All 10 rectangles are not shaded.
0.70 equals a big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 columns of 10 squares each. In the left seven columns, all 10 squares are shaded.
0.7 equals a big square divided into 10 equal vertical rectangles. Seven rectangles from the left are shaded. The remaining 3 rectangles are not shaded.

hints.content: $\green{0.70}$ covers the **same** area as $\blue{0.7}$, so $\green{0.70}$ is **equal** to $\blue{0.7}$.

question.content: **Compare the decimals with $>,<,$ or $=$.**   *Hint: Think about where each decimal is located on the number line below to help you compare.*   $4.4$  $4.28$

images.alt: A number line from 4.2  to 4.5 with tick marks at each one-hundredth unit.
A number line from 4.2  to 4.5 with tick marks at each one-hundredth unit. There is a blue dot labeled 4.28 at the eighth tick mark after 4.2. There is a green dot labeled 4.4 at 4.4.

hints.content: $\green{4.4}$ is located to the **right** of $\blue{4.28}$ on the number line, so $\green{4.4}$ is **greater** than $\blue{4.28}$.

A number line labeled 0 to 3  with tick marks at every one-tenth unit. There is a blue dot labeled 1.9 at the ninth tick mark after 1. There is a green dot labeled 2.4 at the fourth tick mark after 2.

hints.content: $\green{2.4}$ is located to the **right** of $\blue{1.9}$ on the number line, so $\green{2.4}$ is **greater** than $\blue{1.9}$.

hints.content: $\pink{3.6}$ is located at the **same location** as $\blue{3.60}$ on the number line, so $\pink{3.6}$ is **equal** to $\blue{3.60}$.

question.content: **Compare the decimals with $>,<,$ or $=$.**   *Hint: Think about how you would fill in each grid below to help you compare the decimals.*  $3 \text{ tenths}$  $0.65$

images.alt: A big square is divided into 10 equal horizontal rectangles. All 10 rectangles are not shaded.
A big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 rows of 10 squares each. In all 10 rows, all 10 squares are not shaded.
3 tenths equals a big square divided into 10 equal horizontal rectangles. Three rectangles from the bottom are shaded. The remaining 7 rectangles are not shaded.

0.65 equals a big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 rows of 10 squares each. In the bottom 6 rows, all 10 squares are shaded. In the seventh row from the bottom, the left 5 squares are shaded.

hints.content: $\greenD3\greenD{\text{ tenths}}$ covers **less** area than $\blue{0.65}$, so $\greenD3\greenD{\text{ tenths}}$ is **less** than $\blue{0.65}$.

question.content: **Compare the decimals with $>,<,$ or $=$.**   *Hint: Think about where each decimal is located on the number line below to help you compare.*    $5 \text{ ones and } 34\text{ hundredths}$  $5.2$

images.alt: A number line labeled 5.1 to 5.4 with tick marks at every one-hundredth unit.

A number line labeled 5.1 to 5.4 with tick marks at every one-hundredth unit. There is a blue dot at 5.2. The label above the number line is 5.2. There is a green dot at the fourth tick mark after 5.3. The label above the number line is 5 ones and 34 hundredths.

hints.content: $\greenD5\greenD{\text{ ones}}$ and $\greenD{34}\greenD{\text{ hundredths}}$ is located to the **right** of $\blueD{5.2}$ on the number line, so $\greenD5\greenD{\text{ ones}}$ and $\greenD{34}\greenD{\text{ hundredths}}$ is **greater** than $\blueD{5.2}$.

9 tenths equals a big square divided into 10 equal horizontal rectangles. Nine rectangles from the bottom are shaded. The remaining 1 rectangle is not shaded.

hints.content: $\greenD{0.82}$ covers **less** area than $\blue{9\text{ tenths}}$, so $\greenD{0.82}$ is **less** than $\blue{9\text{ tenths}}$.

A big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 rows of 10 squares each. In all 10 rows, all 10 squares are not shaded.
0.8 equals a big square divided into 10 equal vertical rectangles. Eight rectangles from the left are shaded. The remaining 2 rectangles are not shaded.

79 hundredths equals a big square divided into 100 equal sized squares that are set in 10 columns of 10 squares each. In the left seven columns, all 10 squares are shaded. In the eighth column from the left, the bottom 9 squares are shaded.

question.content: **Compare the decimals with $>,<,$ or $=$.**   *Hint: Think about where each decimal is located on the number line below to help you compare.*    $1\text{ one and } 99\text{ hundredths}$  $2.16$

images.alt: A number line from 1.9 to 2.2 with tick marks at every one-hundredth unit.

A number line from 1.9 to 2.2 with tick marks at every one-hundredth unit. There is a green dot at the eighth tick mark after 1.9. The label above the number line is 1 one and 99 hundredths. There is a blue dot at the .sixth tick mark after 2.1. The label above the number line is 2.16.

hints.content: $\greenD1\greenD{\text{ one}}$ and $\greenD9\greenD9\greenD{\text{ hundredths}}$ is located to the **left** of $\blue{2.16}$ on the number line, so $\greenD1\greenD{\text{ one}}$ and $\greenD9\greenD9\greenD{\text{ hundredths}}$ is **less** than $\blue{2.16}$.

question.content: **Compare the decimals with $>,<,$ or $=$.**   *Hint: Think about where each decimal is located on the number line below to help you compare.*   $5.0$  $5 \text{ ones}$

images.alt: A number line labeled 4 to 7 with tick marks at every one-tenth unit.
A number line labeled 4 to 7 with tick marks at every one-tenth unit. At 5, there are two labels. The label above the number line is 5.0. The label below the number line is 5 ones.

hints.content: $\pink{5.0}$ is located at the **same location** as $\blue{5} \blueD{\text{ ones}}$ on the number line, so $\pink{5.0}$ is **equal** to $\blue{5} \blueD{\text{ ones}}$.
